subject: Re: junit.tests.runner.TestCaseClassLoaderTest - ClassNotFoundException
msgSnippet: If you are very new to Java, then please search the web for a tutorial on how to set the CLASSPATH for a Java application I am very new to Java. I executed
messageBody:
"If you are very new to Java, then please search the web for a
tutorial on how to set the CLASSPATH for a Java application"

I am very new to Java. I executed on your advice by using Mastering
the Java CLASSPATH by Keven Boone
(http://www.kevinboone.com/classpath.html). I used Boone's white
paper because it just deals w/ classes and no packages. I needed to
start w/out the complication of package = path. The white paper
resulted in 14 exercises
(http://www.ypl.com/java/environment_variables/class_path/boone_ken/do
c/rl_notes/html/index.html).

Sorry about the delay in response. However, it now seems that I am
going to have to get serious about Java.


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
>
> roberto_lucente wrote:
>
> > OS: Windows NT 4.0 SP6a
> > Java: 1.4.2_04-b05
> >
> > >From the dos prompt I run the following via a .bat
> >
> > set classpath=H:\languages\java\JUnit\junit3.8.1
> > \junit.jar;H:\languages\java\JUnit\junit3.8.1
> > \junit.jar;H:\languages\java\JUnit\junit3.8.1
> > \junit\tests\runner;H:\languages\java\JUnit\junit3.8.1
\junit\samples;
>
> Bad classpath!
>
> Problem #1, you have junit.jar on there twice. Remove one.
> Problem #2, you have ./junit/tests/runner and ./junit/samples on
there,
> which won't work. Remove them, then add:
>
> h:\languages\java\JUnit\junit3.8.1
>
> If you are very new to Java, then please search the web for a
tutorial
> on how to set the CLASSPATH for a Java application.
>
> Good luck.
> --
> J. B. Rainsberger,
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
> Let's write software that people understand
>
